Posts.Content: Me too! First dose of T last Thursday....just waiting for whatever it throws at me!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: #Tigermum i had a real low after FEC3 - I felt very fatigued and generally no energy at all. I don’t think the dark nights helped! I just wanted you to know it did pass and by the time I got to near my first T, I felt a lot better. A good chat with my oncologist helped on my chemo day...planning for next stage, signing consents etc....it just felt like there was light at the end of this really long tunnel.  ️
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I think you sort of go into a time warp! It 8 months since my diagnosis, it seems sooo long ago and yet like yesterday too! I often feel like I am in a bubble and everyone else’s lives are moving on and I’m standing still and can’t really plan anything!  I just keep telling myself that one day soon I can start planning some adventures but in the meantime, when I do feel like getting out and about....I do...
Posts.Title: A year

Posts.Content: Hi i am out the other end now...but had really painful legs with T. I managed to get a cocodomol prescription for last one and it made a huge difference! I had thrown every off the shelf painkiller, gel and bath soak at it but ultimately stronger drugs made all the difference.  As an aside, it has taken me some time to recover and get some energy back....be gentle to yourselves....
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey I had watery eyes for about 2 weeks...then tah-da my eyelashes appeared....growing soooo slowly but they are coming back! No eyebrows yet though...
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Violetsniff this is one of my favourites too...
Posts.Title: For anyone whos struggling <3

Posts.Content: Hi Sorry that you are feeling down....I went to my GP after I was diagnosed and have been on sertraline too through my treatment. Like jowoomot I have found it has really helped me cope and manage my feelings.  It is worth having a chat with your gp....
Posts.Title: Taking anti-depressants or St John’s Wort with letrozole

Posts.Content: I was the same...after my biopsies I noticed cough...couldn’t remember if I’d had it before or not...but became so aware of every little thing. I was convinced it had already spread - it hadn’t . I put it down to anxiety.... Good luck and try to sleep.....
Posts.Title: Just got the dreaded c dianosis help

Posts.Content: Gentle hug sent! It is a difficult time just now but, as I am sure you’ve read elsewhere...it does get better once you know more and have a plan in place. Take each day as they come...try not to plan too far ahead...and pop on here to ask anything.
Posts.Title: Newbie looking for some gentle support

Posts.Content: Lovely that you have thought to ask....what a fabulous friend! Some ideas... Sugar free sweets - Aldi do a good selection A little tube of hand cream  Green tea - I found I went off coffee (which I loved! )  anything for a nice bath....my muscles aches during chemo and baths really helped Maybe a little token...something your friend can take with her to remind her of your friendship i wish her the very best ....xx
Posts.Title: Help for choosing gifts for friend having chemo.

Posts.Content: Having a plan is a great step forwards...i have my last chemo this week and yes it is a long slog but take each day as it comes. One thing I learnt is that everyday is different and whilst one day I might feel really tired or achy...the next day I might feel fine....so my motto has been “this too will pass” and it does. My children are much older but I was amazed at how they just accepted my new ‘do’! My daughter helped me pick hats and we had a giggle trying to tie scarves. There are some excellent wigs available too! I was really unsure about wigs but have a great one which I use occasionally and have had close friends that haven’t noticed... Good Luck next week!
Posts.Title: Got Treatment Plan

Posts.Content: Just to add my experiences, I had a mx and immediate implant. I was happy to go flat but was persuaded to have implant as all-in-one op. Unfortunately I got an infection several weeks later and made the choice to have it removed so I could crack on with my chemo. I went flat and a part of me wishes I hadn’t bothered with the implant - it never really ‘felt’ like me..looked great but just didn’t feel quite right. I would like to have other breast removed but it is low on my priorities and I’m not sure they would do it.... Good Luck RoseKen1....GG
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi It might be an idea to join the monthly chemo threads....I am sure some bright spark can send you a link!  I had FEC -T and am now out the ‘other’ side....reactions vary....i found FEC okay, not great but okay!  I had plenty of anti sickness meds and made sure I got plenty of sleep. I found T harder...maybe because i was already tired and the effects are cumulative. I had quite a lot of pain in my legs but mentioned it to my nurses and they sorted some better pain relief. My advice is to take each day as it comes, keep a close eye on temperature and if your wife is at all concerned ring the hotline number you are given. Tell your breast nurse or chemo nurses any side effects... Stock up on tasty soft drinks....squashes, tonic etc....I found water tasted horrible! Tasty snacks too...as taste buds go to pot! I think you’ll find sweet stuff tastes nicer....I kept frozen pineapple chunks and mango pieces in the freezer. The monthly chemo page on here is really good and whilst everyone is different, I found it helped to know I was not alone. Chemotherapy is hard and I am still recovering but it is doable....and the thread gives loads of hints and tips. I am sure there is a hints and tips page somewhere too....again I am sure one of the super duper Champions will soon point you in the right direction. Wishing your wife minimal side effects.....
Posts.Title: wife about to commence chemotherapy

Posts.Content: The thought of chemo is worse than the reality....in my experience I have had some SEs and they have varied each session. One thing I have noticed is while you might feel tired one day the next day you feel fine. If you have some flexibility in your work that would help....some days you will feel absolutely fine and others you might feel under the weather....and to be honest that sort of sums up my experience. Each day varies...make sure you take the medication offered...I take anti sickness even I feel a little dodgy rather than wait til I feel ill....get some paracetamol in just in case!  And if you feel tired...rest! I just keep thinking it is zapping all those bc cells....GGxx
Posts.Title: So anxious....

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your mum... Please go to the doctor about your concerns, I have always found my gp understanding when it comes to checking out lumps and bumps. i have a family history of bc, aunts on both sides. My mum died of non Hodgkins in her 40s so not sure if she would have had it too! I was referred to a genetics clinic by my doctor and from that I was referred for annual mammograms (I was early 40s). Unfortunately I have subsequently been diagnosed with bc...not seen in mammogram. So my advice is...if you have any worries about lumps that appear...please go and see you gp.
Posts.Title: My mom died at 43

Posts.Content: Hi You have taken the first step in being able to help...there is lots of information on this site and many experiences that can be shared. I had the same type of cancer as your mum, I was diagnosed in June last year so am 8 months into treatment and finish active treatment this week. It is not unusual for information about the cancer to change following the operation - mine did and I too had to go for scans to see if it had spread ( which it hadn’t) I have to say this is probably the most stressful time - the waiting and the unknown - once your mum has a clear idea of what is happening next and the treatment starts...then you manage on a day by day basis. One thing I have learnt is that everyone is different eg their side effects and how they cope. It is useful to take each day as it comes.  I have found my GP/nurse very helpful and I would suggest she makes an appointment to see them...building a relationship may help particularly if she hasn’t really needed to use the doctors much in the past. There may be a support group locally or at the hospital that can also support if you or your sister cannot be there... Timing wise I really don’t think it matters if you go privately as there are guidelines in place through the nhs. I went privately but only as I was covered, Tming is often dictated by your recovery times from operations or chemotherapy rather than availability. Others on this site might be best able to give an insight into nhs or do a search as I know it has been discussed on here before. I hope that helps and I wish your mum all the best.
Posts.Title: My Mum - needs help

Posts.Content: Hey Sorry....but... I had FEC-T and during the T part I lost most of the hair that had started on my head (which I had got quite excited about!), by the end most of lashes and brows had gone too...plus all fuzz of my face...which is bizarre! 4 weeks on my lashes are growing back, some tiny hairs in my brows...my head is a mixture of some fuzz left over from FEC...and a little bit of regrow but still look bald! Really need to be more patient and eyelashes and brows at least make you look a bit more healthy
Posts.Title: Hair returning - but should I get excited?

Posts.Content: The whole thing is crappy, lonely and, I found, boring! Never worry about having a moan or a rant in here...you’ve all done it and felt better for sharing what is a challenging time whether you are surrounded by family and friends or by yourself.... Moan away!
Posts.Title: Loneliness with breast cancer
